Break insert mapping loop if chars don't match any mapping anymore

Fix: insert mapping loop was stopping too long before printing the char

Having 'imap ii <Esc>' takes 'timeoutlen' ms to print i in insert mode in Vim.
We try to emulate the same behavior using sleep 1ms 'timeoutlen' times in our plugin.
How ever there some other operations done and overhead time to take into account at each loop iteration.
For that reason, we increase our time counter by 1.5 instead of 1.

Merge pull request #140 from roryokane/set-default-normal-maps

Revise docs for g:multi_cursor_normal_maps

I make it clear that the default value should work for most people, and describe when people will want to customize the value.

I also made some markup more consistent between the two versions so they are easier to just copy and paste when one version is edited.

And I added spaces to the default value, because I think it’s more important to make the keys of the map clear than it is to make the map shorter, now that it is written on its own line.

Move long default value in docs to under header

When the default value was below the description of the setting, it catches the attention when skimming, but makes it hard to tell what it is for. When it is right below the name of the setting, it should be easier to understand the context.

Move long default value to separate line

I moved the default value to a separate line so that the header doesn’t become very long and wrap.

I changed this in both the README and the Vim documentation so that they are both consistent.

Update tests to expect good normal_maps defaults

I removed the setting of `g:multi_cursor_normal_maps` in a set of examples because it is now unnecessary.

I also changed a test that expected normal-mode `d` to fail. It now explictly expects `d` to fail only when `d` is missing from `g:multi_cursor_normal_maps`.

Update docs in README too

Updated the default for `g:multi_cursor_normal_maps` in the README as well as the documentation

I am worried that this will make the header too long, but I can’t really tell until I see this published on GitHub.

Update setting default in documentation

Documented the new default for `g:multi_cursor_normal_maps`

I removed the spaces after the commas in the value, because Vim doesn’t highlight helpfile text in backticks if it contains spaces.

I couldn’t think of any obvious way to write this long value readably without breaking up the flow of the text too much, so I just let it go off the edge of the screen.

Set good defaults for g:multi_cursor_normal_maps

I identified these multi-key mappings by going across the keyboard, row by row, and checking whether that key, or Shift plus that key, was a multi-key mapping by default.

I manually tested this change by removing the setting from my vimrc and making sure that the listed keys were still handled correctly, and that they weren’t when the dictionary was set to empty.

First posted in my comment https://github.com/terryma/vim-multiple-cursors/issues/21#issuecomment-75443638.

fix #89 Add individual paste buffers to cursors

With this commit you can use multiple cursors to yank/paste and they will use
their own block of text as expected. In Visual mode operations `y` and `Y` are
supported. In Normal mode, all operations that change unname register are
supported (`dcsx`) but only few motions are supported (e.g. `cw`, `ciw`, `caw`,
`ci(`, and so on, but no support for `ctx` or `c/pattern<cr>`).

For best experience, use these options in your ~/.vimrc:

    let g:multi_cursor_normal_maps = {'d': 1, 'c': 1}
    let g:multi_cursor_exit_from_insert_mode = 0
    let g:multi_cursor_exit_from_visual_mode = 0

Merge pull request #105 from balta2ar/use-word-boundary

Add support for searching whole words
Mention g:multi_cursor_start_word_key in doc/multiple_cursors.txt
Mention g:multi_cursor_start_word_key in README.md
Do not use word boundary in Visual mode

Add support for searching whole words

VIM's * command searches for the whole word -- it wraps current word with word
boundaries: \< and \>. g*, on the other hand, does not care about word
boundaries.

This patch adds functionality to configure multiple cursors behaviour to be
consistent with VIM's * and g*. To do that, use newly introduced option:

    let g:multi_cursor_start_key='g<C-n>'
    let g:multi_cursor_start_word_key='<C-n>'

Note that in current implementation "start word" command works in both Normal
and Visual modes.
Update README.md

Merge pull request #1 from aschrab/folding

Open folds around new cursors

Open folds around new cursors

If changes are made with a cursor inside of a closed fold, the entire
fold will be treated as if it was selected rather than just the matched
portion of it.  To avoid this open all folds around new cursors.

Merge branch 'master' of github.com:terryma/vim-multiple-cursors

Fix regression on out of sync cursors.

- Fix 1 regression where cursors could potentially get out of sync in insert
  mode
- Added some logic to debug latency. Fanning out to 30 cursors in insert mode
  with my vimrc took over 300ms. It's like than 20ms with a plain vimrc. Need to
  debug what setting is causing the slowing down in insert mode and inform
  users.
Update README.md

Chain undos together in insert mode. Prevent ghostly cursors.

This commit provides basic chaining of undos in insert mode. Previously, undos
of changes made in multicursor mode are done one character at a time. This
change should chain all inserts into a single undo block, and undo them
together. This fixes #22.
We're also adding support to detect non-terminating single key commands. For
example, previously, 'd' would break multicursor mode and cause these ghostly
cursors to linger on screen, where the only way to get rid of them is to press
`<C-n>` somewhere to start a new multicursor mode. Now, these unterminated
commands are detected and simply cause a nop, execution continues and we're left
in multicursor mode. This paves the way to support multikey commands in the
future. This fixes #28.

Merge branch 'master' of github.com:terryma/vim-multiple-cursors

Major refactoring to reduce time remained in visual mode.

This also fixes visual line mode, which fixes #25
Update README.md

Fix regression that causes call stack to explode with too many cursors.

The special keys needs to be handled with feedkeys instead of calling them
directly, since the latter would continue to grow the previous call stack
eventually cause maxfuncdepth to kick in with a few dozen cursors. Also rename
to internal <Plug> mappings to be shorter to squeeze a tiny bit of perf
Update doc to mention that only single keys and special keys can be mapped

Finally fix the annoying highlight problem with the last cursor.

This is a (harmless) hack that addresses the problem with the highlighting of
the last cursor if it's the last character on the line.

Stop chaining dictionary function calls.

This fixes #10 and fixes #11. Apparently some version of Vim don't like the
notation a.b().c() very much. Break up the chain by introducing a temp var
Forgot to update CHANGELOG
Merge branch 'master' of github.com:terryma/vim-multiple-cursors

Exit Vim's visual mode before waiting for next user input.

This fixes #14. In GUI Vim, Vim's visual selection seems to take over the cursor
highlight. By quitting Vim's visual mode, we let the plugin's visual selection
show instead.
Update README

Don't use clearmatches(). It clears highlighting from other plugins.

This fixes #13.

Fix documentation error.

The correct mapping for the key to quit multicursor mode is
"g:multi_cursor_quit_key" and not "g:multi_cursor_exit_key"

Change mapping from using expression-quote syntax to using raw strings.

This fixes #6. This change should allow Mac keys like Cmd-D to be mapped
correctly. Previously, keys are mapped using the expression quote syntax, which
gets turned into raw key code in the map command. The keycode makes it easy to
check for input when doing getchar() in multicursor mode, but appears to cause
problems with the noremap command, and is really not a standard way to map keys
anyway. This change now uses raw strings, and convert the raw string to a
keycode at runtime (using some voodoo exec magic)

Fix two bugs. Add CHANGELOG

1. Restore view when exiting from multicursor mode. This fixes #5
2. Remove the unnecessary user level mapping for 'prev' and 'skip' in visual
mode, since we can purely detect those keys from multicursor mode

Stop hijacking escape key in normal mode

Fixes #1, Fixes #2, Fixes #3. Hijacking the escape key was a convenience that
caused more harm than good. Its only purpose is to clear out any lingering
cursors due to unexpected user commands. Pressing CTRL-N in normal mode should
do the same. Updated the doc to highlight this fact. In the future, we might
want to provide a command that explicitly calls reset()
Add Vim doc, update README, and add LICENSE
Update README
Initial release
